speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me when you first noticed this rash, and was it present at birth or did it appear after some time?

speaker: Patient
text: It started yesterday, I woke up to it, and my mom said it was there when I was born, but I didn't notice it myself, I was asleep.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the rash in more detail - is it itchy, scaly, or does it seem to be a blistering reaction?

speaker: Patient
text: It's a bit itchy, but mostly it's just a red, squishy feeling on my skin. I can see tiny bumps on it, and it's pretty spread out all over my body, but I noticed it's not on my hands or feet like my mom said it was.

speaker: Doctor
text: So the rash was present at birth. That's quite unusual. Can you tell me if the rash seems to be spreading or if it's more localized to a specific area of the body?

speaker: Patient
text: It seems to be getting a bit more widespread today, but it's still mostly confined to my trunk and arms. I can see it spreading to my legs, though.

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me if the rash seems to be affecting any of your vital organs, such as your skin is itchy, scaly, or does it seem to be a blistering reaction?



Is the baby's overall behavior and appetite normal, despite the rash?



Can you tell me if there's any family history of similar skin conditions in the parents?

text:

speaker: Doctor
text:
I've taken a closer look at the rash, and I notice it's more widespread across the body, but seems to be more concentrated on the torso. I see that it's a pinkish hue, almost like a mild erythema.
